message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Phencyclidine (PCP) is a dissociative anesthetic that can cause vertical nystagmus, which is the most specific physical finding for PCP intoxication. Constricted but responsive pupils are associated with opioid intoxication, and dilated, minimally responsive pupils are associated with sympathomimetic drugs. Conjunctival injection is associated with cannabis intoxication.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Phencyclidine is known to cause horizontal or vertical nystagmus. The other options are not commonly associated with phencyclidine use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of previous ED visit for phencyclidine-related agitation suggests the current episode may also be related. Vertical nystagmus is a classic physical finding associated with PCP use. Constricted pupils (option B) can be seen with opioids and other sedatives, while dilated pupils (option C) can be seen with stimulants. Conjunctival injection (option D) is a non-specific finding and can be seen in a variety of conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's previous ED visit for phencyclidine-related agitation and current symptoms suggest PCP intoxication. The most specific sign of PCP intoxication is prominent vertical nystagmus. Constricted pupils are more commonly associated with opioids and dilated pupils with stimulants. Conjunctival injection may be seen in a variety of conditions but is not specific to PCP intoxication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Phencyclidine (PCP) use can cause vertical nystagmus, which is the most strongly suggestive physical finding for this diagnosis. Constricted but responsive pupils are observed with opioid use, dilated minimally responsive pupils are seen with sympathomimetic use, and conjunctival injection is seen with cannabis use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of a previous ED visit for phencyclidine-related agitation suggests that the current episode may also be related to this drug. Among the physical findings, prominent vertical nystagmus is most strongly associated with phencyclidine intoxication. Constricted pupils suggest opioid intoxication, dilated pupils suggest sympathomimetic intoxication, and conjunctival injection is non-specific.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of phencyclidine-related agitation suggests the possibility of phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication. Among the physical findings listed, prominent vertical nystagmus is most strongly associated with PCP intoxication. Constricted but responsive pupils are more consistent with opioid intoxication, while dilated and minimally responsive pupils are more consistent with central nervous system depression or anticholinergic toxicity. Conjunctival injection may be seen in various conditions, including alcohol intoxication and marijuana use, but it is not specific to PCP intoxication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Phencyclidine (PCP) is a dissociative anesthetic that can cause vertical nystagmus. Constricted pupils are seen with opioid intoxication, while dilated pupils are seen with sympathomimetic toxicity. Conjunctival injection is a non-specific finding that can be seen with many types of intoxication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of previous ED visit for phencyclidine-related agitation, along with the current presentation of responding to hallucinations and diaphoresis, suggests the possibility of phencyclidine intoxication. Among the physical findings, prominent vertical nystagmus is the most specific for phencyclidine intoxication. Constricted but responsive pupils are associated with opioid intoxication, dilated minimally responsive pupils with sympathomimetic intoxication, and conjunctival injection with alcohol intoxication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication can cause prominent vertical nystagmus, which is the most strongly suggestive physical finding for this diagnosis. Constricted but responsive pupils suggest opioid intoxication, dilated/minimally responsive pupils suggest anticholinergic toxicity, and conjunctival injection suggests alcohol or cannabis intoxication.
